column4: i am running ssh server but i would like to use public/private keys in stead of regular password so anyone can help?
what is the problem exactly with using SSH keys?
OK.  That is not a problem.. Go ahead and use them...
Ask if you have questions after that.
Keep reading, see the section "Tip: Generating Public Keys" :-)
It runs ssh-keygen with appropriate params to geenrate a public key....
You need to create that authorized-keys file to include the keys you decide are authorized :-)
Did you run the ssh-keygen command?
Look in your ~/.ssh/ dir and see what files you have there?
There should be both id_rsa (the secret key) and id_rsa.pub (the public one)
Right, so you have both private and public key files there.... OK?
Yes, in principle.  The PC you will be logging in from runs Ubuntu, right?
For some other ssh apps you may have to "import" the key and convert it to a different file format
The doc I linked to before has some info about using Putty from WIndows, for example.
you can just copy the id_rsa and id_rsa.pub files to another Ubuntu PC into the ~/.ssh dir and use them from there
Not 100% needed, but the public key is public anyway and keeping them together makes sense.
